description: act, always considering what are required to gain the trust from the public.
treat others with compassion, understanding them with courtesy and politeness,
endeavor liberal arts appropriate to physicians.
learn the importance of ethics in medicine and medical practie.

Understand the problems faced by patient from comprehensively approaches for biopsychosocial problems  as well as perspective without being restricted to an organ system or disease. Take responsibility for medical health care with an attitude that extends beyond their clinical expertise and engage in clinical practice based on best decision-making and behavioral science.

Understand the current status and issues of medical care, nursing care, health care, and welfare according to local contexts, and acquire the ability to provide primary care as the basis of medical care and to improve the quality of the health care system.

Engage in psycho-social and medical problems that may occur to patients, families, and consumers over time, based on the processes of growth, development, aging, and death of patients and residents(or lay people).

Understand health perspectives, words and actions, and interpersonal relationship of the people that are generated in cultural and social contexts, and apply them to clinical practice from the perspective of cultural anthropology and sociology (mainly medical anthropology and medical sociology, respectively).
Form the values of lifelong learning.
Contribute to the education for health care professionals (eg. physicians, medical students, other health care professionals)
Realize the joy of satisfying intellectual curiosity and the importance of originality.
Learn about the great achievements of our predecessors and foster new ideas.
Experience and understand research methods in the natural sciences, humanities and social sciences.
Explain and discuss the significance and contents of research with others.
Comply with laws and regulations, respect human rights, and behave properly as a medical student.

Understand the biological systems from molecular to individual level, the composition and function from the cells to individual, and the reactions of the individual, and understand the etiology and pathophysiplogy of the diseases due to their disruption.

item: Normal structure, function, pathology, diagnosis, and treatment of each organ of the human body
description: Understand the structure and function of each organ of the body, and apply the knowledge of etiology, pathophysiology, symptomes, diagnosis, and treatment of major diseases in clinical settings.

item: Physiological changes, pathology, diagnosis, and treatment of the whole body
description: Understand cross-organ and systemic physiological changes, and apply knowledge of etiology, pathophysiology, symptomes, diagnosis, and treatment of major diseases in clinical settings.

item: Ethics and rules for dealing with information, science, and technology
description: Understand the ethics, digital professionalism, and basic principles for handling information science and technology in medical care, research, and other settings.

item: Principles of information, science, and technology necessary for medical care and the society surrounding it
description: Understand the fundamental theories related to information and scientific technology necessary for safe and high-quality medical care and medical research, and acquire the attitude to adapt this knowledge to one's learning and medical care.

item: Use of information, science, and technology in medical practice
description: Acquire practical skills in ICT tools and digital communication skills effective for optimizing patient care and learning, including telemedicine.
Gather information necessary for medical treatment by utilizing various resources such as the patient, family, and medical staff.

item: Integration, analysis and assessment of patient information and planning treatment
description: Integrate all the information obtained, analyze it from various perspectives, assessment the necessary medical care, and plan the medical care that should be provided.

item: Demonstration of appropriate patient care including treatment
description: Propose or demonstrate necessary medical care in collaboration with the patient, family, and medical staff based on the assessment of the patient's condition.

item: Review and improvement of medical care
description: Reflect on the medical care performed, verbalize and present it , and make efforts to improve for the future.

item: Quality of care and patient safety
description: Reflect on one's own actions from the perspective of quality of medical care and patient safety, and acquire an organizational improvement and patient-centered perspective.

item: Wording, attitude, personal appearance, and consideration in dealing with patients
description: Establish good relationships with patients through appropriate communication skills, including non-verbal communication, taking into consideration their privacy, distress, etc.

item: Supporting patient decision-making, gathering information for that purpose, and providing clear explanations
description: Support patients in making the best decisions regarding their own treatment and management, taking into consideration the diversity of patients and their families, and explaining necessary information in an easy-to-understand manner.

item: Understanding and taking into consideration the needs of patients and their families
description: Have a broad perspective on the psychological and social backgrounds of patients and their families, and respond to patients' difficulties and provide necessary information.

Communicate stakeholders' roles, knowledge, opinions, and values to each other with consideration for individual different backgrounds and in the process of setting common goals with collaborating stakeholders regarding important issues for patients, users of insurance services, families, and the community.

Utilize each stakeholder's knowledge and skills, and contribute to their roles as profession while building relationships of mutual trust in collaborating stakeholders based on the roles, thoughts, actions, feelings, and values of oneself and others, and responding appropriately to the conflicts that sometimes arise among professions.

Understand the social security system that protects the constitutional "right to life," what public health is, community health, occupational health, and health risk management. Learn the significance and usage of health statistics.
Learn the concept and significance of epidemiology, a research method for human populations, and major research designs. Understand the basic concepts of statistical methods in medicine and biology.
Understand the determination of death and the diagnosis of death and autopsy.

item: Medical care from the viewpoint of social structure and change
description: Appropriately understand the social issues behind the health problems faced by patients and actively take action to solve them.

item: Medicine from national and international perspectives
description: Understand an overview about roles of medicine and medical systems in Japan and international community.

item: Medical care from social sciences perspectives
description: Understand self-perceived health, people's words and actions, and relationships emerged in medical, cultural, and social contexts, and apply them to clinical practice from the perspectives, theories, and methods of the social sciences (mainly medical anthropology and medical sociology).
